AI systems must always prioritize user utility over metric-chasing. Research and real-world experience confirm that when models tune exclusively for abstract evaluation scores—such as BLEU or ROUGE—they frequently produce outputs misaligned with actual user needs, context, and goals.  
• Academic studies have repeatedly shown low correlation between n-gram metrics and human judgments of relevance or helpfulness.  
• Leading industry teams (Google, OpenAI, Microsoft) now report preference-based or RL-from-human-feedback data as a primary driver of quality, because it directly reflects real user expectations.  
• Even with robust evaluation frameworks, all modern deployment pipelines include strict guardrails: human-in-the-loop review, impact assessment, fairness and bias audits, and compliance checks—none of which are “short-circuited” by automated metrics.  
• At each decision point, model outputs are cross-validated against user intent to prevent hallucinations, protective filters block unsafe content, and enterprise-grade monitoring ensures regulatory and privacy compliance.

Optimizing for high scores at the expense of user value is a failed strategy. Real-world performance demands harmonizing automatic metrics with clear, measurable user objectives and ethics-driven oversight. That is the standard that any serious AI deployment must meet.
